conclusion: Understanding the problem about the Stirling cycle and its P-V diagram.
Recalling the Stirling cycle involves two isothermal and two isochoric processes.
Point A is at high pressure and low volume; B is at lower pressure and higher volume; C is at low pressure and high volume; D is at higher pressure and lower volume.
A to B is an isothermal expansion; C to D is an isothermal compression.
D to A is a constant volume process because the volume doesn't change.
Recalling the Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution and its dependence on temperature.
If temperature changes during D to A, the rate distribution curve will change.
From D to A, temperature increases at constant volume.
Since temperature increases, the rate distribution curve shifts towards higher speeds and broadens.
The rate distribution curve changes from D to A because temperature increases.
Confirming that temperature is the only factor affecting the rate distribution.
Final conclusion: Yes, the rate distribution curve changes from D to A.
